title: God Destroys Assyria, Which Is a Type of the Destruction of the Wicked at the Second Coming
html:
2 Nephi 20:12–14. "I will punish . . . the king of Assyria" After the Lord uses the wicked king of Assyria to do his work of punishing covenant Israel, the Lord will destroy Assyria. The king boasts of his accomplishments in verses 13–14.

2 Nephi 20:15. The ax gets the ax Which is greater, the tool or the carpenter? The Lord illustrates that although the Assyrian king believes he did all these things on his own, he was only a tool in the carpenter's hand.

2 Nephi 20:16. "His fat ones" Fat is a symbol of prosperity, and the prosperous king of Assyria will soon experience "leanness."

2 Nephi 20:17. Round Up the briers and thorns These weeds are referred to elsewhere as symbols for the wicked or worldly influences. (See comments on 2 Nephi 15:5–6).

2 Nephi 20:17. "In one day" This phrase can mean in a short time, or it can also mean, literally, in one day (as we will discover later in this chapter).

2 Nephi 20:18–19. "His forest" Again, trees often symbolize people in Isaiah, and here the king of Assyria's forests, or armies, will be hewn down, until there are so few left that a child may "write" or "count" them (notice footnote 19a).
